name: Significant sounds
description: The arrival of synchronised sound dramatically changed the movie business, allowing filmmakers to use sound in new and exciting ways which developed the use sound into own film language.

key_work.title: Arrival of sound
key_work.brief_description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. Actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the ‘Talkie Terror’, but when Don Juan and The Jazz Singer debuted, there was no turning back.

links.description: Fritz Lang’s M features in the Arrival of sound, despite lacking a film score. Lang instead used the leitmotif, pioneering the use of associating a character, place or situation with a recurring musical piece, which was most common in opera.

end.brief_description: Seven noble families fight for control of the mythical land of Westeros. Friction between the houses leads to full-scale war. All while a very ancient evil awakens in the farthest north. Amidst the war, a neglected military order of misfits, the Night’s Watch, is all that stands between the realms of men and icy horrors beyond.

constellations_other.description: This Constellation tracks how an on-set in-joke became one of the first cinematic easter eggs. It was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Harrison Buikstra and Jasper Caverly.

links.description: The Legend of Zelda also makes frequent use of leitmotifs to articulate characters, locations and concepts. Musical themes are used to give greater awareness of story development like the use of Ganondorf’s theme, which represents Ganondorf or one of his alternate forms.
